t: Proverbs 6
Financial Entanglements
My*pn son, if you have put up security for your neighbor or*ln entered into an agreement with a stranger,
you*ln have been snared by the words of your mouth — trapped*ln by the words from your mouth.
Do*ln this, then, my son, and free yourself, for*ln you have put yourself in your neighbor’s power: Go,*ln humble yourself, and plead with your neighbor.
Don’t*ln give sleep to your eyes or*ln slumber to your eyelids.
Escape*ln like a gazelle from a hunter, like*ln a bird from a hunter’s trap.
Laziness
Go*pn to the ant, you slacker! Observe*ln its ways and become wise.
Without*ln leader, administrator, or ruler,
it*ln prepares its provisions in summer; it*ln gathers its food during harvest.
How*ln long will you stay in bed, you slacker? When*ln will you get up from your sleep?
A*ln little sleep, a little slumber, a*ln little folding of the arms to rest,
and*ln your poverty will come like a robber, your*ln need, like a bandit.
The Malicious Man
A*pn worthless person, a wicked man goes*ln around speaking dishonestly,
winking*ln his eyes, signaling with his feet, and*ln gesturing with his fingers.
He*ln always plots evil with perversity in his heart; he*ln stirs up trouble.
Therefore*ln calamity will strike him suddenly; he*ln will be shattered instantly, beyond recovery.
What the Lord Hates
The*pn Lord*s hates six things; in*ln fact, seven are detestable to him:
arrogant*ln eyes, a lying tongue, hands*ln that shed innocent blood,
a*ln heart that plots wicked schemes, feet*ln eager to run to evil,
a*ln lying witness who gives false testimony, and*ln one who stirs up trouble among brothers.
Warning against Adultery
My*pn son, keep your father’s command, and*ln don’t reject your mother’s teaching.
Always*ln bind them to your heart; tie*ln them around your neck.
When*ln you walk here and there, they will guide you; when*ln you lie down, they will watch over you; when*ln you wake up, they will talk to you.
For*ln a command is a lamp, teaching is a light, and*ln corrective discipline is the way to life.
They*ln will protect you from an evil woman, from*ln the flattering tongue of a wayward woman.
Don’t*ln lust in your heart for her beauty or*ln let her captivate you with her eyelashes.
For*ln a prostitute’s fee is only a loaf of bread, but*ln the wife of another man goes after a precious life.
Can*ln a man embrace fire and*ln his clothes not be burned?
Can*ln a man walk on burning coals without*ln scorching his feet?
So*ln it is with the one who sleeps with another*ln man’s wife; no*ln one who touches her will go unpunished.
People*ln don’t despise the thief if he steals to*ln satisfy himself when he is hungry.
Still,*ln if caught, he must pay seven times as much; he*ln must give up all the wealth in his house.
The*ln one who commits adultery lacks sense; whoever*ln does so destroys himself.
He*ln will get a beating and dishonor, and*ln his disgrace will never be removed.
For*ln jealousy enrages a husband, and*ln he will show no mercy when he takes revenge.
He*ln will not be appeased by anything or*ln be persuaded by lavish bribes.
